Generator.name: Xper3
Generator.notes: This software is developed by LIS - Laboratory of Informatics and Systematics (UniversitÃ© Pierre et Marie Curie, UMR 7205, France) - www.infosyslab.fr

Representation.Label: Foliar descriptors referencial
Representation.Detail: Une base de tp très light pour comprendre le fonctionnement d'xper

Representation.Label: Whorled
Representation.Detail: Three or more leaves arranged in a circle around a central axis (leaves around a stem).

Representation.Label: Decussate
Representation.Detail: Arranged along the stem in pairs, with each pair at right angles (at 90°) to the pair above or below

Representation.Label: Palmately compound
Representation.Detail: A leaf with separate subunits (leaflets) attached at the apex of petiole (like the fingers of a hand).

Representation.Label: Ternate (trifoliate)
Representation.Detail: A compound leaf with three leaflets attached to one point.

Representation.Label: Pinnately compound (odd-pinnate + even pinnate)
Representation.Detail: A leaf with leaflets arranged along a rachis. Leaf with uneven number of leaflets and ending in a terminal leaflet, so that there is an odd number of leaflets = odd-pinnate. Leaf with even number of leaflets and ending in a terminal pair of leaflets, so that there is an even number of leaflets = even-pinnate.

Representation.Label: Bipinnate (twice pinnately compound)
Representation.Detail: Compound leaf dissected twice with leaflets arranged along rachillae that are attached to the rachis.

Representation.Label: Tripinnate (thrice pinnately compound)
Representation.Detail: A compound leaf with leaflets attached to secondary rachillae that are in turn attached to rachillae, which are borne on the rachis.

Representation.Label: Base swollen
Representation.Detail: Petiole thickens at the base where it attaches to the node.

Representation.Label: Pulvinate
Representation.Detail: Having an abruptly swollen portion near the petiole that functions to permit leaf movement.

Representation.Label: No petiole
Representation.Detail: The leaf does not have a petiole. It joins the stem directly. For example: the sheath of the leaf.

Representation.Label: Laminar size
Representation.Detail: The laminar size is determined by measuring the area of the leaf. An approximation can be made by measuring the length and width of the leaf in millimeters and multiplying the length x width x 2/3. The following chart shows the ranges of areas for the different leaf classes (Webb 1955).

Representation.Label: Laminar shape
Representation.Detail: The simplest way to describe the overall shape of the lamina is to locate the axis or, in some cases, the zone of greatest width that lies perpendicular to the axis of greatest length (long axis).

Representation.Label: Elliptic
Representation.Detail: In the shape of an ellipse, or a narrow oval; broadest at the middle and narrower at the two equal ends In lobed leaves the blade shape is determined from an ellipse drawn around the apices of the lobes. The widest part of the ellipse is then considered as in unloved leaves.

Representation.Label: Obovate
Representation.Detail: Egg-shaped with the broadest part near the apex.

Representation.Label: Ovate
Representation.Detail: Egg-shaped with the broadest part near the base.

Representation.Label: Oblong
Representation.Detail: Longer than broad, with the margins parallel for most of their length.

Representation.Label: Special
Representation.Detail: Leaf is not described by any of the shapes illustrated here (such as a needle or awl)

Representation.Label: Symmetrical
Representation.Detail: Lamina approximately the same shape on either side of the midvein.

Representation.Label: Asymmetrical
Representation.Detail: Lamina different size or shape on either side. Not divisible into equal halves.

Representation.Label: Base asymmetrical
Representation.Detail: Base of the lamina of markedly different shape on either side of the midline.

Representation.Label: Base angle
Representation.Detail: The vertex of the base angle lies in the center of the petiole at the point where the basal most laminar tissue touches the petiole. Base angle is the angle from the vertex to the points where a line perpendicular to the midvein at 0.25lm from the base intersects the margin. In leaves with a basal extension, the base angle should be measured from the same vertex point to the basal most points of the leaf on each side. The base angle is always mea- sured on the apical side of the rays even in leaves where the angle is greater than 180°. Peltate leaves are defined as having a circular angle.

Representation.Label: Wide obtuse
Representation.Detail: A special case of obtuse such that the base angle is >180°.

Representation.Label: Apex angle
Representation.Detail: Apex angle is the angle from the apical termination of the midvein to the pair of points where a line perpendicular to the midvein and 0.75lm from the base intersects the margin. In leaves with an odd number of lobes, measure the apex angle as in unlobed leaves. In leaves with an apical extension the apex angle should be measured using the termination of the midvein as the vertex, and the apices of the lobes on either side. The apical angle is always measured on the basal side of the rays, even in leaves where the angle is greater than 180°.

Representation.Label: Wide obtuse
Representation.Detail: A special case of obtuse such that the apex angle is >180°.

Representation.Label: Base shape
Representation.Detail: These states apply to the basal 25 percent of the lamina.

Representation.Label: Cuneate (straight)
Representation.Detail: The margin between the base and 0,25L has no significant curvature.

Representation.Label: Convex or Rounded
Representation.Detail: The margin between the base and 0,25L curves away from the center of the leaf or forms a smooth arc across the base.

Representation.Label: Truncate
Representation.Detail: Subtype of convex in which the base terminates abruptly as if cut, with margin perpendicular to the midvein or nearly so.

Representation.Label: Concave
Representation.Detail: The margin between the base and 0,25L curves toward the center of the leaf.

Representation.Label: Concavo-convex
Representation.Detail: The margin between the base and 0,25L is concave and convex on the base.

Representation.Label: Decurrent
Representation.Detail: Subtype of either concave or concavo-convex in which the laminar tissue extends basally along the petiole at a gradually decreasing angle.

Representation.Label: Complex
Representation.Detail: There are more than two inflection points in the curve of the margin between the base and 0,25L.

Representation.Label: Cordate or Lobate
Representation.Detail: Heart_shaped, with the notch at the base. The margin can be concave (=cordate), straight or convex (=lobate).

Representation.Label: Sagittate
Representation.Detail: Triangular at the base with two acute lobes pointing downwards, like an arrow-head.

Representation.Label: Hastate
Representation.Detail: Arrowhead_shaped, but with the basal lobes turned outward rather than downward; halberd_shaped.

Representation.Label: Marginal
Representation.Detail: Petiolar insertion at the margin of the leaf.

Representation.Label: Peltate central
Representation.Detail: Petiole attached within the boundaries of the leaf margin and near the center of the leaf.

Representation.Label: Peltate eccentric
Representation.Detail: Petiole attached near the edge but inside the boundaries of the leaf margin.

Representation.Label: Apex shape
Representation.Detail: These states apply to the apical 25 percent of the lamina.

Representation.Label: Straight
Representation.Detail: The margin between the apex and 0,75L has no significant curvature.

Representation.Label: Convex or Rounded
Representation.Detail: The margin between the apex and 0,25L curves away from the center of the leaf or forms a smooth arc across the apex.

Representation.Label: Truncate
Representation.Detail: The apex terminates abruptly as if cut, with margin perpendicular to the midvein or nearly so.

Representation.Label: Acuminate
Representation.Detail: The margin between the apex and 0,75L is concave, curving toward the center of the leaf, or is convex basally and concave apically. This category includes most drip tips.

Representation.Label: Complex
Representation.Detail: There are more than two inflection points in the curve of the margin between the apex and 0,75L.

Representation.Label: Retuse
Representation.Detail: With a very slight notch at the top.

Representation.Label: Emarginate
Representation.Detail: With a notch at the top. More marked than for "Retuse", heart-shaped.

Representation.Label: Lobed
Representation.Detail: Lobed form, the lamina is curved towards the inside of the base.

Representation.Label: Margin type
Representation.Detail: TEETH are marginal projections with sinuses indented less than 1/4 of the distance to the midvein or long axis of the leaf. Teeth can be either dentate, serrate or crenate. Note: If there is a single tooth of any size, the leaf is considered to be toothed.

Representation.Label: Dentate
Representation.Detail: Teeth pointed with their axes perpendicular to the trend of the leaf margin.

Representation.Label: Serrate
Representation.Detail: Teeth pointed, pointing towards the apex, with their axes inclined to the trend of the leaf margin.

Representation.Label: Crenate
Representation.Detail: With rounded teeth along the margin, without a pointed apex.

Representation.Label: Revolute
Representation.Detail: Margins are turned under or rolled up like a scroll, toward the underside.

Representation.Label: Erose
Representation.Detail: Irregularly toothed, eroded, appearing as if nibbled.

Representation.Label: Teeth/cm
Representation.Detail: The number of teeth/cm in the middle 50 percent of the leaf.

Representation.Label: (Tooth) spacing
Representation.Detail: This refers to the interval between corresponding points on the teeth or crenations.

Representation.Label: (Tooth) shape
Representation.Detail: Tooth shape is described in terms of the shape of the apical side and the basal side. The possible combinations are shown in the chart below. The apical shape is listed first. For example, cc/fl would be concave on the apical side and flexuous on the basal side of the tooth. Note that a given leaf can exhibit more than one tooth shape.

Representation.Label: Sinus (shape)
Representation.Detail: The shape of the sinus of the tooth.

Representation.Label: (Tooth) apex
Representation.Detail: There are three major types of tooth apex: simple, spinose, and glandular. In living leaves and some fossils, it may be possible to distinguish the following subsets of glandular: spherulate, papillate, foraminate, mucronate, and setaceous. For situations in which a more specific identifica- tion is not possible, use non-specific glandular.

Representation.Label: Simple
Representation.Detail: Tooth apex formed by the change in direction of the leaf margin without additional elements.

Representation.Label: Non specific glandular
Representation.Detail: In fossils, it may be impossible to distinguish between the different subtypes of glandu- lar teeth. This character state is reserved for the descrip- tion of fossil teeth with a visible concentration of material on the tooth apex.

Representation.Label: Spinose
Representation.Detail: Principal vein of tooth projecting beyond the apex (spines or similar).

Representation.Label: Spherulate
Representation.Detail: Having a spherical callosity fused to the apex.

Representation.Label: Papillate
Representation.Detail: Having a clear, nipple-shaped, glandular apical termination.

Representation.Label: Foraminate
Representation.Detail: With an apical cavity or foramen that broadens from the termina- tion of the principal vein toward the exterior.

Representation.Label: Mucronate
Representation.Detail: With an opaque or non-deciduous cap or mucro fused to the tooth.

Representation.Label: Setaceous
Representation.Detail: An opaque, deciduous bristle or cap thickened proxi- mally and not fused firmly with the remaining tooth substance.

Representation.Label: Lobation
Representation.Detail: LOBES are marginal indentations that reach 1/4 or more of the distance to the midvein, measured parallel to the axis of symmetry of the lobe.

Representation.Label: Actinodromous
Representation.Detail: Three or more primary veins diverging radially from a single point.

Representation.Label: Palinactinodromous
Representation.Detail: Primaries diverging in a series of dichotomous branching, either closely or more distantly spaced.

Representation.Label: Flabellate
Representation.Detail: Several to many equally fine basal veins diverge radially at low angles and branch apically.

Representation.Label: Acrodromous
Representation.Detail: Three or more primaries veins starting at the base of the leaf and finishing toward the leaf apex.

Representation.Label: Paralleodromous
Representation.Detail: With two or more veins starting at the base of the leaf, running parallel to the leaf margin and meeting (or almost meeting) at the apex.

Representation.Label: Campylodromous
Representation.Detail: Several primary veins or their branches, originating at or near a single point and running in strongly recurved arches that converge apically.

Representation.Label: Brochidodromous
Representation.Detail: Secondaries joined together in a series of arches.

Representation.Label: Eucamptodromous
Representation.Detail: In which the secondary veins bend towards the margin of the leaf, moving towards the apex, but do not form curls.

Representation.Label: Festooned brochidodromous
Representation.Detail: Having one or more additional stes of loops outside of the main brochidodromous loop.

Representation.Label: Cladodromous
Representation.Detail: Secondaries freely branching toward the margin.

Representation.Label: Reticulodromous
Representation.Detail: Secondaries branching into a reticulum (inter-connected like the meshes of a net) toward the margin.

Representation.Label: Craspedodromous
Representation.Detail: Secondaries go directly from the central vein to the margin (ordinarily in the toothed leaves).

Representation.Label: Semicraspedodromous
Representation.Detail: Secondary veins branching just within the margin, one of the branches terminating at the margin and the other joining the superadjacent secondary (ordinarily in toothed leaves). Can have one or more additional sets of loops outside the branch that joins the superadjacent 2°.

Representation.Label: Intramarginal vein
Representation.Detail: Secondaries end in a strong vein closely paralleling the leaf margin.

Representation.Label: Acrodomous
Representation.Detail: With two or more veins starting at the base of the leaf, running parallel to the margin and meeting (or almost meeting) at the apex.

Representation.Label: Interior
Representation.Detail: Secondary veins crossing between primary veins or secondary veins, that do not reach the margin- typically arched or straight.

Representation.Label: Uniform
Representation.Detail: The spacing between the secondary veins is substantially the same.

Representation.Label: Irregular
Representation.Detail: The spacing between the secondary veins is irregular.

Representation.Label: Decreasing toward base
Representation.Detail: The spacing between the secondary veins decreases as they approach the base.

Representation.Label: Increasing toward base
Representation.Detail: The spacing between the secondary veins increases as they approach the base.

Representation.Label: Uniform
Representation.Detail: The angle of the secondary veins is substantially equal.

Representation.Label: One or two pair acute basal secondaries
Representation.Detail: A pair or two of basal veins very acute compared to others.

Representation.Label: Increasing toward base
Representation.Detail: The angle of the secondary veins increases (strongly or smoothly) towards the base.

Representation.Label: Smoothly decreasing toward base
Representation.Detail: The angle of the secondary veins decreases smoothly towards the base.

Representation.Label: inter 2° veins
Representation.Detail: Intersecondary veins have a width and course similar to the 2°s, but they are usually thinner than the costal 2°s and do not reach the margin.

Representation.Label: Opposite percurrent
Representation.Detail: The tertiaries pass between the secondary and traverse them parallel without branching.

Representation.Label: Alternate percurrent
Representation.Detail: The tertiaries cross the secondary with an offset (an abrupt angular discontinuity) with branching.

Representation.Label: Mixed opp/alt
Representation.Detail: Tertiaries have both types of "percurrent" courses (opposite and alternate).

Representation.Label: Random reticulate
Representation.Detail: The tertiaries join (anastomosis) other tertiary or secondary with random angles.

Representation.Label: Dichotomizing
Representation.Detail: Tertiaries end freely, without joining other veins.

Representation.Label: Regular polygonal reticulate
Representation.Detail: The tertiaries join (anastomosis) other tertiary veins to form polygons of similar size and shape.

Representation.Label: Straight
Representation.Detail: passing across the intercostal area without a noticeable change in course.

Representation.Label: Convex
Representation.Detail: The middle portion of the vein curving away from the center of the leaf.

Representation.Label: Sinuous
Representation.Detail: There is a changing direction of the curvature.

Representation.Label: Admedially ramified
Representation.Detail: The tertiary veins branch out, oriented towards the primary or midline vein, without joining the secondary veins.

Representation.Label: Exmedially ramified
Representation.Detail: Les veines tertiaires se ramifient entre elles, orienté vers la marge de la feuille, sans rejoindre les veines secondaires.

Representation.Label: 3° vein angle variability
Representation.Detail: The tertiary angle is measured with respect to the primary vein.

Representation.Label: Inconsistent
Representation.Detail: Angle of the tertiaries varies randomly over the lamina.

Representation.Label: Uniform
Representation.Detail: Angles of the tertiaries do not vary over the surface of the lamina.

Representation.Label: Increasing exmedially
Representation.Detail: The angles of the tertiaries become more obtuse by moving away from the primary vein.

Representation.Label: Decreasing exmedially
Representation.Detail: The angles of the tertiaries become more acute by moving away from the primary vein.

Representation.Label: Increasing basally
Representation.Detail: The tertiary angles become more obtuse toward the base of the lamina.

Representation.Label: 4° vein category
Representation.Detail: Fourth and higher order venational characters should be scored in the portion of the leaf that is roughly half way between the base and the apex unless the area is lacking.

Representation.Label: Alternate percurrent
Representation.Detail: The 4° veins cross between adjacent tertiaries with an offset (an abrupt angular discontinuity).

Representation.Label: Opposite percurrent
Representation.Detail: The 4° veins cross between adjacent 3os in parallel paths without branching.

Representation.Label: Regular polygonal reticulate
Representation.Detail: The 4° veins anastomose with other veins to form polygons of similar size and shape.

Representation.Label: Dichotomizing
Representation.Detail: The 4° veins end free without ramifications and are the finest vein order the leaf exhibits.

Representation.Label: Regular polygonal reticulate
Representation.Detail: The veins anastomose with other veins to form polygons of similar size and shape.

Representation.Label: Dichotomizing
Representation.Detail: 5° veins branch and are the finest vein class that the leaf exhibits.

Representation.Label: Areolation
Representation.Detail: Areoles are the smallest areas of the leaf tissue surrounded by veins; taken together they form a contiguous field over most of the area of the lamina. Any order of venation can form one or more sides of an areole.

Representation.Label: Lacking
Representation.Detail: (rare) venation that ramifies into the intercostal area without producing closed meshes.

Representation.Label: Poorly/Moderately developed
Representation.Detail: Areoles many sided (often >7) and of highly irregular size and shape.

Representation.Label: Well developed
Representation.Detail: Areoles of relatively consistent size and shape.

Representation.Label: F.E.V.S
Representation.Detail: “FEVs” are the freely ending ultimate veins of the leaf. The two database fields should contain the extreme states observed.

Representation.Label: Unbranched
Representation.Detail: No branches, may be linear or curved.

Representation.Label: Incomplete loops
Representation.Detail: Freely ending veinlets adjacent to the margin.

Representation.Label: Looped
Representation.Detail: Marginal ultimate vein recurved to form loops.

Representation.Label: Fimbrial vein
Representation.Detail: Higher vein orders fused into a vein running just inside the margin.

Representation.Label: Number of basal veins
Representation.Detail: The number of 1°, 2°, and 3° veins originating at or near the the base of the leaf/top of the petiole.

Source.href: https://dl.dropbox.com/s/n8tto9oregkb79a/One or two pair acute basal secondaries.jpg
